name: CALORIE - Taste of Remembering
description:
Wistful Sunday mornings over chai and biscuits listening to the pattering of rain.
Roasted rotis and sharing fragrant curries around a dining table.
Goldeny sweet jalebes that capture the rich lights of festivals. Memories of food is more than its taste.

Join us on a walkthrough of Calorie where we explore food as nostalgia! Through art, stories, and interactive moments, we will explore the meals we once ignored, the flavors we miss the most, and the small rituals that quietly shaped us.

Come for the stories, stay to colour.

name: After the First Bite: Leftovers Potluck
description:
Have you ever been to a leftovers potluck? 

Led by Ritaban Ghosh, this potluck examines whether hygiene and edibility are shaped by our beliefs and habits that we inherit, choose, or find difficult to leave behind. Is disgust a property of things, or an emotion that shapes moral codes? Is food (or waste) often a matter of attitude?

Whether it’s pasta from a sunday brunch or rasam from the time you caught a cold. The older, the better. Plates will be exchanged and passed around after every bite. Eating in relay, we’ll pause at different stages of the food’s life, before it becomes waste, or perhaps doesn’t at all.

Learn how to turn leftovers into consumable capsules and create a mind map on where edibility is withdrawn, how habits are reciprocal, and when refusal becomes aesthetic.

Participants are invited to bring leftovers.

name: To Eat or Not to Eat? On Edibility
description:
Sunday mornings often begin with a peek into the fridge with wilted greens, sprouting spuds and a questionable stench, followed by the question: to eat or not to eat? Deciding what to consume and what to discard is a perennial struggle. In doing so, we enter uneasy intimacies shaped by affordance, access and surplus. 

In this talk, Ritaban Ghosh examines food and waste, asking: where does the boundary between purity and contamination lie? What truly determines edibility? He traces the processes through which food comes to be classified as waste, while moving across the globe, where repurposed food becomes sustenance. From Mexico’s *Huitlacoche*, a regional corn fungus delicacy, to Indonesia’s *Kopi luwak*, coffee beans collected from Civet excrement, food is far more complex than we often assume.

name: Math is Fun: How Folding Paper Creates Mathematics
description:
Can we find mathematics outside of textbooks?

Join Disha as she explores mathematics through the art of paper folding. In particular, examining criteria for flat-foldability. Which is the conditions under which a given crease pattern can be folded flat and pressed inside a book without crumpling. 

Through hands-on folding, participants will formulate conjectures, test their validity, and prove some of them together. No advanced mathematical background or prior experience with origami is required. Come with the curiosity to learn and a willingness to fold paper. Participants will not just get to take home the origami model that they fold, but also the mathematical ideas that emerge from the folding process.

name: Prompt Kitchen
description:
How much is a quarter teaspoon? How do you fold in cheese?

Recipes rely heavily on verbal instructions, and following them is often confusing. The Interaction Design Team from the National Institute of Design (NID) is reimagining how recipes are communicated. In this workshop, participants will generate custom recipe templates that are tangible, paper-based visual layouts for the ingredients and steps. They’ll delve into prompt engineering and recipe visualisation and ultimately design an interactive and spatial recipe. So that the next time you’re in the kitchen, following a recipe feels intuitive and fun, not confusing.

The workshop is designed for anyone interested in cooking from beginners to home cooks.

name:
Educator Workshop: 
Interdisciplinary Thinking In Practice
description:
Click here to [register]! 

Learning is often presented as distinct, neatly defined subjects.
Interdisciplinary thinking integrates them, opening up a word that is complex, interconnected, and full of surprises!

The Educator Workshop is a full-day immersive workshop for educators from across the city, to explore new ideas, think across disciplines, and reimagine learning together. Because the future of education is becoming increasingly interdisciplinary.

What to expect?
> Experience our exhibition-season CALORIE, where ideas from science, art, design, and society intersect.
> Unpack interdisciplinarity through hands-on activities and reflective discussions.
> Explore NCERT topics through a fresh lens.
> Collaborate in small groups to design practical ideas for sparking interdisciplinarity in the classroom. 
> Present your insights in a lively pitching session.

Who is this for?
Educators and teachers across subjects (Classes 7–12) who value curiosity, inquiry, and exploring ideas across disciplines.


Come, be a learner for a day.
Connect with fellow educators.
Return inspired—with practical tools and renewed energy for teaching.
